The biggest flaw in almost all methods of measuring animal welfare is ignoring the negative value of death itself. This is a huge error, but I think we can correct for it fairly easily.

In most cases, people have a much stronger desire to avoid death than they do to avoid suffering. Outside of depression and mental illness, this tends to hold true in almost all cases except for the most extreme and hopeless forms of suffering, such as truly excruciating pain from a terminal disease.

1 in 5 people live with chronic pain and the vast majority of them don’t even think about suicide, yet alone act on it. So even people with intense and unending pain usually would prefer to live with that pain than die.

It seems intuitively obvious that animals have similar preferences, given how deeply rooted a desire to avoid death is in our collective evolutionary biology. Any animal that wasn’t willing to experience pain over death would have died out a long time ago and the same evolutionary pressures that caused us as humans to value our own lives so much have most likely affected all animals in the same way.

So to measure the true negative value of death within the same framework we use to measure welfare, we can ask ourselves one simple question: how much pain and suffering is the average person willing to experience in order to avoid death?

The negative value of death then must be equivalent to an amount of suffering that is so extreme, prolonged and inevitable that any rational person would choose death to end it.

That leads me to think that for most animals, despite the fact that we cause them extreme and prolonged pain in our food system, the worst thing we do for their welfare is killing them. Especially because the pain we inflict on animals is very far from inevitable, it’s a direct result of the conditions we inflict upon them.

It’s actually hard to imagine the sheer level of torture you would have to inflict on someone (whether human or otherwise) for them to actually prefer you would have killed them instead.

The idea that killing someone is amongst the worst things you could possibly do to them if you care about their welfare is very uncontroversial when we’re talking about humans, and it’s also actually pretty uncontroversial when we talk about companion animals too.

If you had to choose between someone punching your healthy, happy dog in the face (causing them pain, but not killing them) or shooting them in the back of the head while they sleep (killing them, but not causing them pain), you’d probably struggle to find anyone who thinks that shooting them is genuinely the better choice for their dog’s welfare.

The fact that killing someone who doesn’t want to die is amongst the worst things we can do for their welfare is entirely uncontroversial and it’s time for us to apply that equally towards all animals.

The best thing about working from home is that when my dog has a panic attack in the middle of the day for no apparent reason, she can just cuddle me on the couch until she feels better ❤️

Avra didn't have an easy start to life as a victim of abuse living on the streets that narrowly avoided death when she ended up in the shelter system. 

When I first started fostering her (which didn't last long because I ended up adopting her pretty much straight away), it would sometimes take her days to recover from a panic attack. 

Today, it only took her a few minutes of cuddling on the couch to recover from her first panic attack in nearly two years.

The biggest misconception about Open Paws is thinking that we are trying to build a Large Language Model like ChatGPT from scratch. This has never been our goal.

Our focus is on building a massive database with reliable information on animal rights issues and veganism, ranked by animal advocates for relevance, ethical alignment, trustworthiness, logic, emotional impact, and cultural sensitivity.

This database will contain scientific studies, research reports, social media marketing analytics, campaign materials, statistics, examples of successful campaigns, website content, and more.

Every intervention at the intersection of AI and animal advocacy requires gathering data first, not just training custom models.

If you want to use existing AI models and ensure they’re giving reliable responses, you need a database like this to ground its responses in factual information.

If you want to influence third-party AI models to be more animal-friendly, you need a database like this for those companies to extract data from.

If you want to train animal advocacy organizations on using AI tools effectively, you need a database like this for them to add their own data, so their AI can provide contextually relevant responses.

We will start by training predictive models to estimate how content will perform across various metrics, including social media engagement, political influence, donation potential, and more. These models can be used as standalone tools to test content variations before going live or combined with existing AI tools to filter out bad responses and return the best ones.

Only after we’ve done all of that, funded entirely by free cloud computing credits, will we look at fine-tuning existing open-source LLMs, not training any new ones from scratch.

Our approach, based on an extensive literature review of over 1,000 research papers on ML and AI, is scientifically sound, technically implementable, and will significantly improve AI performance on animal advocacy tasks for a fraction of the cost of training an LLM from scratch.

We will start with a state-of-the-art open-source LLM and continue pre-training on our niche-specific database before fine-tuning using our predictive models as the reward function. This ensures the AI gains a deeper understanding of animal advocacy facts and is optimized to create real-world change for animals, not just repeat common viewpoints.

Meanwhile, this technology is only part of our work. We’ve given over 50 free consultations to animal advocacy organizations, prepared policy reports, advised students, built custom AI-powered automations, made VEG3 freely available to over 5,000 users, surveyed nearly 200 animal advocacy organizations about their AI use, presented at conferences, developed academic research agendas, and engaged with major AI labs.

Yet, the misconception persists that we are solely focused on building a new Large Language Model from scratch.

💹 IT systems
💹 Financial systems
💹 Staff training
💹 Fundraising processes
💹 Talent 
💹 Communications

which are all "overheads" - and typically not fundable.

Funders don't want to pay for overheads - even though it would improve impact and impact measurement.

Most funders allocate between 10% to 20% of their donation to cover them - but research shows most overheads absorb 17% to 35% of costs. 

So even on the "shoe-string" budget, the real costs are not being covered.

So why don't charities invest in the above themselves??

If a charity invested in IT for example, and got rid of all the outdated and highly manual systems - it would be better for the staff (less burn out) and the service users (if it improved the quality, quantity or speed of service).

It might be expensive to implement but could save money in the mid and long term. 

But charities don't because it would (a) spike those overheads in year one (b) wouldn't get funded if it was considered an overhead.

So, staff compensate for lack of resources and service users suffer.

And charities continue to report low overheads and high impact to conform to funders' wishes/pressure.

But the more charities report doing well on low overheads - the more funders believe it's possible.

Throw in deeply ingrained behaviour and a power imbalance - and you're stuck in a vicious circle.

It's call "The Starvation Cycle" (which I've tried to illustrate in the carousel below).

Within the animal rights movement, I’ve seen a lot of very minor disagreements between advocates cause disproportionate amounts of division and harm to our movement. 

I’ve been reflecting a lot on why this happens, who it benefits and what we can learn about it from the great social justice movements of the past. As I’ve been thinking about this, I’ve found that history and psychology both have a lot to teach us about this topic. 

From a historic perspective, we can see that virtually all successful social justice movements have been disrupted by their opposition, who have intentionally exacerbated disagreements and created division in order to weaken those movements.

COINTELPRO, a covert operation where the FBI infiltrated and disrupted various social justice groups, is a great example of this, and thanks to many declassified documents, we know exactly what kind of tactics they used to divide and conquer these movements.

An FBI agent describing COINTELRPO said “in every instance, consideration should be given to disrupting the organized activity of these groups and no opportunity should be missed to capitalize upon organizational and personal conflicts in their leadership.”

From a psychological perspective, humans are particularly vulnerable to this kind of exploitation due to the "narcissism of small differences." This concept suggests that the more a community shares commonalities, the more likely its members are to engage in interpersonal conflicts and ridicule. 

This happens because the more we consider a community to be part of our identity, the more our ego subconsciously wants that community to be smaller, so that we in turn feel more special for being part of it. 

The end result is that strong, united and powerful movements fracture into a disorganised mess of increasingly smaller and weaker factions that refuse to co-operate with each other, a process that is driven just as much by the natural flaws of human psychology as it is by those who benefit from seeing this flaw exacerbated.

So whenever you find yourself disagreeing with another advocate in the animal rights movement, ask yourself these two questions.

First, is this disagreement objectively large enough to justify the level of division it is causing? If someone from outside of our movement were to see this disagreement, would they consider our views to be as different as we believe them to be, or would our views look very similar from an external perspective?

Second, is this disagreement making the movement stronger or weaker? And if this disagreement is weakening the movement, who benefits the most from that?

Imagine animal exploitation as a tree, with its roots representing the speciesist ideology that underpins it, the branches as the specific forms of animal abuse, and the leaves as the individual animals suffering.

Some people advocate "hacking at the branches" - working on welfare reforms, or “cutting off leaves” - liberating individual animals.

These actions have an immediate impact on animal lives, but they might not take down the whole tree.

Others say we should focus on striking at the "roots" by educating about anti-speciesism.

This can certainly take down a tree, but it takes a very long time to dig up every last root.

But if you ask anyone who has actually chopped down a real, non-metaphorical tree, they’ll tell you most effective way to do it is to strike at the trunk.

The trunk of a tree is the target that’s both within immediate striking distance (unlike the roots) and so critical to the functioning of the system that the tree can’t survive without it (unlike the branches).

We take chunks out of this trunk whenever our actions do real financial damage to the industry. Campaigning for governments to remove subsidies on animal products, getting significant segments of the population to boycott animal products and taking direct action that causes economic harm to this industry are all examples of striking at the trunk.

This doesn't mean we should ignore the roots or the branches - saving leaves in the meantime is still important and ultimately we still need to remove the roots to prevent the tree from growing back.

But as any tree-cutter will tell you, the trunk is the best place to start.

The animal rights movement would be significantly stronger if we truly believed and acted like we have the ability to end animal exploitation within our lifetime.
This is something I genuinely believe and it makes me sad to see so many animal advocates who don’t.

If you don’t believe that ending animal exploitation is possible in your lifetime, you generally either a) feel so defeated you do nothing or b) aim too low and focus only on achieving minor reforms or changing the beliefs of a few individuals, not eradicating entire industries.

Clearly, this belief is not a helpful one if your ultimate goal is to end animal exploitation.

But in addition to being unhelpful, this belief is also wrong.

There has never been a time in human history where change has happened as fast as it’s happening right now. That’s true across every benchmark of our evolution as a species, from cultural to biological to technological and more.

That rate of change isn’t slowing down either, it’s accelerating. We can change more in a single year now than we could have in a decade or even a century in earlier parts of human history. And in every year that follows, we’ll be able to change more than we did in the previous one.

There’s still clearly a lot of work to do. But if every person in the world who has the goal of achieving animal liberation in their lifetimes truly believed and acted like it was possible, I have no doubt that we could collectively do the work needed to make it happen.

The use case for AI in animal advocacy I’m most excited about is also one of the hardest ones to explain: the powerful combination of prediction, generation and automation. But it’s really, really worth understanding for all animal advocates, so I’m going to break it down in the simplest way I can. ⬇️

Humans make predictions all the time in our advocacy, for example, we might predict which message is most likely to resonate with a specific individual in a conversation about veganism.

But imagine how much more accurate our predictions would be if they were based on millions or even billions more conversations about veganism. That might not be possible for a human to do, but it’s definitely possible for an AI to do, with access to enough data.

By combining the data gathered by many different animal advocates and animal advocacy organisations, we can train AI that can make far better predictions about what will and won’t be successful in our advocacy.

In this example I’ve used conversations about veganism, but you can also do this with literally any metric that’s being tracked digitally. You can do it with predicting the performance of digital advertisements, predicting the likelihood of passing legislation, predicting which companies are most likely to respond to corporate advocacy, predicting the likelihood of success for different grant applications and much, much more.

Once you have an AI model that can accurately predict a result, you can use it to train generative AI models that only generate content that is likely to achieve that result. You do this by having the generative AI model (for example, something like ChatGPT) create multiple versions of content, then using your predictive AI to predict what the results would be and finally using that prediction as either reward or punishment in the generative AI’s learning process.

When you run this process for long enough on a large enough dataset, you get superhuman performance at achieving the result you’re after.

Then once you have your new generative AI model, which has been trained by the predictive AI model, you can begin automating its actions. For example, you could set up an automation so that any time someone uses an anti-vegan hashtag on social media, the AI responds automatically in the way most likely to convince that individual person to consider veganism.

It’s actually really hard for me to picture even a single type of animal advocacy intervention that wouldn’t benefit from an AI trained this way, because the only criteria is either having some kind of metric or goal being tracked digitally and/or there being some kind of digital content about that type of intervention existing online.

So when people ask me to name the one specific use case or intervention where AI can help animals the most, the honest answer is also the one that is the hardest for people to get their heads around: all of them.

Effective altruism is right logically, but it’s wrong culturally.

The core principle of effective altruism is extremely admirable. The goal of not only wanting to do good, but to do as much good as you can, is one we should all aim for.

Beyond that, relying on evidence to guide your decisions and being open to changing your perspective based on new evidence is also extremely important to anyone trying to do good in the world.

In terms of the logical arguments alone, it’s clear that effective altruism wins the debate. Clearly it’s better to be “effective” in our altruism than “ineffective” in our altruism.

However, something as complex as changing the world requires far more than just logic.

Culture and emotion have just as much (if not more) of an effect on human behaviour than logic does. If we expect to influence behaviour using logic alone (whilst ignoring emotion and culture) we will never live up to our full potential for effectiveness.

To be truly effective in our altruism, we need to be much more effective in our dealings with emotion and culture, both internally and externally.

In practical terms, here are 3 ways I believe the culture of effective altruism could change to make it substantially more impactful by dealing with emotions in a more healthy way.

1) Be more welcoming and inclusive to new people, ideas and beliefs. That means allowing them space to grow whilst nurturing and encouraging them towards becoming more effective, rather than shutting them down for not being perceived as effective enough already. There’s a time and place for more critical feedback, as well as a right way to give it, and generally this requires greater sensitivity to emotion and culture, even if logic is on your side. This principle applies equally to people, ideas and beliefs, as all of these can suffer from a lack of inclusion.

2) Meet people where they are and focus on getting them to take the first step towards being more effective, instead of focusing too much on the end goal. That might mean encouraging someone to simply look for more effective charities within the cause area they already care most about, rather than encouraging them to switch cause areas entirely. Or, it might simply look like encouraging any form of donation at all, regardless of whether or not it’s to the most effective charities. Remember that on average most people donate less than 1% of their income and less than 10% of people have even heard about effective altruism, so things that might seem like small steps to us could feel like giant leaps to most people.

3) Stop using academic jargon and start communicating in a more accessible way. This kind of language excludes the vast majority of the population who don’t understand all of the terms that effective altruists use. It creates an unnecessary barrier to entry and makes the community feel elitist and unwelcoming.

Do you have any other ideas for how the culture of effective altruism could be improved?

If there’s one thing the animal rights movement urgently needs, it’s much less competition and much more collaboration.

This situation calls for a broader systemic shift in the AI industry's approach to speciesist biases. To drive real change, we need open-source datasets, evaluations, and models that are aligned with animal rights and we need an organisation that not only actively builds those resources, but also actively advocates for all AI companies to use them to make their AI more animal-aligned.

In my talk, I discussed the power of AI technology in legal advocacy for animals, highlighting how it can revolutionize the way we fight for their rights.

Whether or not we achieve animal liberation in our lifetime depends almost entirely on one factor: how soon animal advocates develop and learn to use specialised AI.

If you've only used AI for things like writing blogs or managing emails, that might sound a bit far-fetched. But to really understand why this is the case, you have to first understand the astronomical difference in performance between specialised AI and generic AI.

It's incredibly challenging to create an AI that excels in every human task, and despite recent AI advancements, we’re still not there yet. But we've already been able to design AI that outperforms humans in specific tasks for decades.

For example, AI beat the world champion chess players way back in 1997 and has since surpassed human abilities in various areas, from solving complex scientific problems like protein-folding to forecasting weather more accurately than human experts.

The animal industry has already spent years (and in many cases, decades) developing and implementing their own specialised AI systems. McDonald’s uses predictive AI to decide which menu items are most likely to drive sales (and even in some cases to entirely automate order-taking), JBS uses AI to optimise sorting carcasses and factory farms use predictive analytics to make their operations cheaper and more efficient.

The animal advocacy movement, on the other hand, has fallen extremely far behind. We're hardly using even basic AI tools, let alone developing specialised ones.

Meanwhile, technical progress in AI is skyrocketing. Every day, over 100 new machine learning studies are published on Arxiv and nearly every major industry has already developed specialised AI for their needs.

If an AI trained in 1997 could beat the world's best human chess player, today's AI could easily outperform the best human animal advocates. An AI advocate wouldn't get burnt out, could be endlessly replicated and improved, could respond 24/7, and could draw from the entire collective knowledge of the animal advocacy movement.

Training this AI doesn't need huge technological breakthroughs, most of it is already possible to build with open source foundational models. We just need data (which our movement has plenty of) and funding for computing power (which we have much less of, but still more than enough).

Our mindset is the only barrier. If we, as a movement, agree on the importance of developing and using our own specialised AI, I'm convinced we can achieve animal liberation in our lifetime.

I've been an animal rights activist for more than 10 years. Five of those were spent working full-time as the Australia and New Zealand Outreach Manager for an international animal rights group.

But way back when I first became an activist, I had absolutely zero understanding of marketing. 

If anything, I actually thought marketing was a bad thing! I thought it was just a way that the companies who are harming the planet manipulate us into buying things we don't need.

That all changed when I read these books.

Previously my activism had been based on complete guesses about what I THOUGHT would influence people's behaviour for the better.

But these books showed me that by using marketing analysis tools, I could actually KNOW what was and wasn't working to influence people's behaviour.

The more I learned about marketing, the more effective my activism became. And the more effective my activism became, the more I learned about marketing.

It's been a long journey and I've learned a lot, but the most important thing I've learned about marketing, activism and life in general is this.

Your strategy should never be based on assumptions. It should always be based on evidence. 

Firstly, the evidence that already exists (and there's always a lot of it). 

Secondly, the evidence you gather yourself through the ART of creating completely new approaches and the SCIENCE of rigorously testing the results.
